page.title: 12THE WARTIME BASE AT EGMERE
page.content: Early in 1943, the{Air Ministry}built an airfield on some land at Egmere for U.K. and Norwegian airforces. The run- ways were laid by the ladies of the {Land Army.}It became a base for{Short {Stirling Bombers}and was named North Creake Airfield.{199 squadron}was formed in 1944 to fly missions known as{'window dropping'.}Strips of tin foil were dropped to fool German radar into thinking there were whole squad- rons of planes. The one plane lost from this squadron was painted as a mural on one of the shed walls by{Fl. {Sgt. Allan}(now deceased) and under it were the words CHOP 17-6-44 RIP. It was removed in 1984 and presented to {Hendon Bomber Museum.}It was unveiled by Fl.Sgt. Allan's widow on 17-6-84, forty years to the day.{Mosquito} fighter planes came here near the end of the war. Much evidence is extant.
